thread.title: The things you should NEVER do on holiday

author: Caroline Mcguire for MailOnline
title: The things you should NEVER do on holiday
text:
25 shares 30
View
comments
Holidays are supposed to be the point in a year when the batteries are recharged, with travellers returning home refreshed after a week of relaxation.
But often, a stupid mistake on vacation can turn the trip into a nightmare, leaving tourists wishing they'd stayed at home.
From running out of fuel on the motorway in Germany to wearing camouflage in Barbados and forgetting to flush in Singapore, the are numerous laws in countries around the world ready to trip you up and ruin a holiday.
In other places, the most important things to avoid are in Mother nature, like the poisonous Manhineel tree in the Bahamas.
MailOnline has looked at some of the many things to avoid doing in countries around the world to ensure your next holiday is problem free...
Don't take pictures of the women in the windows of the Red Light District in Amsterdam
In Amsterdam, tourists can get into serious trouble for photographing the women posing in the windows of the Red Light District
The scantily-clad prostitutes who pose in the windows of the Red Light District are as much of an attraction for customers wishing to purchase their wares as tourists who want to catch a glimpse of the famous sights.
But if you do head down there, don't even think about taking a picture of the women as it is prohibited and you will most likely get in trouble.
 2 Next Hotel accidentally sends loyal customers number for PHONE... Intoxicating India: Breathtaking pictures of the colour and... Forget saving for a holiday, now travellers are crowdfunding... Don't run out of petrol on a German motorway
There are many rules in German that could prove problematic for an unsuspecting tourist, among them a ban on refusing entry to a chimney sweep and rules against noisy housework on a Sunday.
But one that could cause a hefty fine is the mistake of running out of fuel on an autobahn.
The government has implemented a law against any unnecessary stops on the motorway, which applies to drivers who have run out of fuel.
Don't wear camouflage in Barbados
In Barbados, only the Barbados Defence Force are allowed to wear camouflage
In Barbados, it is illegal to wear camouflaged clothing - and even children can find themselves in trouble if they wear military-style attire.
The only people allowed to wear the clothing is the Barbados Defence Force.
Only smoke in designated places in Kenya
In Kenya, there a strict rules on where it is legal to smoke. This does not include shopping centres, restaurants or even outside in the bush.
People caught flouting the law can be fined or even sent to prison.
Don't get into an empty subway car in New York
It is inadvisable to ever choose an empty subway carriage in New York
The subway can be a handy way to travel around the Big Apple, but it is also very hit and miss.
If there is an empty carriage during rush hour it's for a reason, for instance, a lack of air conditioning or a urine-covered floor.
Equally, don't get into an empty carriage late at night four your own safety.
Don't forget to flush the loo in Singapore
The Singapore government has many rules about cleanliness, the most famous being the ban on chewing gum.
But there is another rule which could easily catch you out - the rule against forgetting to flush.
Anyone forgetting to pull the chain after leaving the toilet can be find up to Â£100.
Don't sit under the manchineel tree in the Bahamas
The manchineel is one of the most poisonous trees in the world and even standing underneath it in the rain can be seriously damaging
The manchineel is one of the most poisonous trees in the world and its fruit should never be eaten.
But even sitting underneath the tree during a thunderstorm is inadvisable as its milky white sap causes strong allergic dermatitis.
Even a small amount of sap mixed with the rainwater would cause the skin to blister.
Don't order an 'Irish Car Bomb' in Ireland
In America, the popular cocktail of Guinness, Bailey's and Jameson's whisky is ordered by asking the barman for an 'Irish Car Bomb'.
Unsurprisingly, this would not go down well in Ireland as it refers to the many car bombings that took place during the Troubles in the country.
Don't take pictures of the police or soldiers in Cuba
Taking pictures of the police or soldiers in Cuba is illegal
Taking pictures of the police or soldiers in Cuba is illegal and if spotted, you could be treated harshly.
The same applies to anyone who photographs bridges, dams, or anything else of strategic value.
Don't kiss in public in Dubai
Because of strict Muslim laws, visitors to Dubai could find themselves in trouble over drinking alcohol, sharing a hotel room when unmarried and even holding hands.
Sex outside of marriage is illegal and sharing a hotel room could land you in a police cell.
Holding hands is tolerated if you are married, but kissing and hugging is considered an offence against public decency.
Don't die in Sarpourenx
This would be a tough rule to enforce as once a person is dead, it is impossible to fine or imprison them, but in Sarpourenx, in southwest France, people who don't have a plot in the cemetery who still wish to be buried in the village are forbidden from dying there.
According to a 2008 rule by the mayor, those who do will be severely punished.
